content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle," "defect," "motor vehicle," "motor vehicle safety," "motor vehicle safety standard," "person," and "rental company." It specifies that a covered vehicle is a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes by a rental company. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" prohibits the rental, lease, and sale of defective cars and trucks. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" prohibits rental companies from renting, leasing, or selling vehicles with safety defects unless the issue has been fixed before the transaction. Exceptions apply if a notification ordered by the Secretary of Transportation is challenged in a civil action. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" prohibits rental companies from renting vehicles with safety defects unless fixed beforehand. Exceptions apply if a notification ordered by the Secretary of Transportation is challenged in a civil action. Rental companies must promptly inform renters and authorized drivers of any defects during the rental period. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" requires rental companies to immediately notify renters and authorized drivers of any safety defects in rented vehicles and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. This section of the Act will be effective 60 days after its enactment. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" mandates rental companies to inform renters of safety defects in rented vehicles and provide a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost. Violations of the Act will be enforced by the Federal Trade Commission under the same rules as the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties for violations will be in line with the Federal Trade Commission Act. States also have enforcement authority under the Act. The attorney general of a State can bring a civil action in a US district court for violations of the Act, seeking injunctive relief. Prior notice to the Federal Trade Commission is required before initiating such action. The attorney general of a State must notify the Federal Trade Commission before initiating a civil action for violations of the Act. The notice should include a copy of the complaint. If immediate notice is not feasible, it should be provided upon instituting the action. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in the action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. The Federal Trade Commission can intervene in civil actions, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. State attorney generals can still exercise their powers under state laws and proceed in court for alleged violations. No separate suit can be brought if the same violation is already subject to a pending action by the FTC or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will cover buying practices, safety implications, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers. SEC. 8. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration report on sales of motor vehicles by rental companies with safety defects before recall. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will focus on sales of covered vehicles by rental companies that are aware of safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. The report will cover the period from when the rental companies become aware of the issues to when they receive a notification from the Secretary of Transportation. The report to Congress will analyze the frequency of sales of rental vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. It will cover the period from awareness of issues to notification by the Secretary of Transportation. The report to Congress will include an analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance with safety standards. It will also discuss the effects of these sales on consumers and provide recommendations for legislative and administrative actions to address or mitigate these issues. Additionally, a follow-up report on the sales of covered vehicles will be submitted to Congress within one year of the initial report.
